Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the group chat with my family lighting up with messages about the big holiday dinner this weekend. My stepmom had sent a long text about how important it was for all of us to be there, especially since it was the first time we’d all be together since Dad remarried. I knew how much it meant to her, and to my dad, for me to show up and be part of the family, to help make things feel normal and united.

But then my phone buzzed again—this time, a message from Mia. She’d just gotten home, her words shaky and short. She’d been passed over for a promotion she’d worked so hard for, and I could hear the tears in her voice when I called. She needed me, needed someone to listen, to hold her, to remind her she was more than her job.

I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of both expectations pressing down on me. I wanted to be the supportive boyfriend Mia deserved, but I also didn’t want to let my new family down. My chest tightened as I tried to figure out how I could possibly be in two places at once.
